questions.text: Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of a drug used for diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (IBS-D), that is approved only for women and is associated with a risk of ischemic colitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

5-HT₃ receptor antagonist

Explanation:
The drug in question is alosetron, which is:
•    Approved only for women with severe IBS-D who have not responded to conventional treatment.
•    A highly selective 5-HT₃ (serotonin type 3) receptor antagonist.
•    It reduces visceral pain, gastrointestinal motility, and secretions, helping control diarrhea and discomfort in IBS-D.
Adverse Effect:
•    A rare but serious side effect is ischemic colitis, which led to temporary market withdrawal.
•    The drug is now available under a restricted prescribing program due to safety concerns.
Other Options:
•    A. D₂ antagonist – E.g., metoclopramide; used for nausea/gastroparesis.
•    C. 5-HT₄ agonist – E.g., tegaserod; used in IBS with constipation, not diarrhea.
•    D. Motilin receptor stimulant – E.g., erythromycin; used for prokinetic effects in gastroparesis.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts at the site labeled "D" in the diagram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tolcapone

Explanation:
•    Site D in the diagram is in the brain, where dopamine is degraded by the enzyme COMT (Catechol-O-Methyl Transferase) into 3-MT (3-Methoxytyramine).
•    Tolcapone is a COMT inhibitor that works in both the periphery and the CNS.
It inhibits central COMT, reducing dopamine breakdown in the brain and prolonging dopamine’s action → leading to improved motor control in Parkinson’s disease.
Therefore, it acts at site D.

Other Options:
A. Entacapone →  Incorrect. Acts only in the periphery (site B), not in the brain. Does not affect central COMT.
B. Selegiline →  Incorrect. This is a MAO-B inhibitor, which acts at site C, not D.
D. Benserazide → Incorrect. This is a DOPA decarboxylase inhibitor that acts in the periphery (site A), preventing conversion of levodopa to dopamine outside the brain.

questions.text: Which monoclonal antibody is known to interfere with blood grouping and cross-matching, necessitating careful planning before transfusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Daratumumab

Explanation:
Daratumumab is an anti-CD38 monoclonal antibody used primarily in the treatment of multiple myeloma. CD38 is not only expressed on myeloma cells but also expressed at low levels on red blood cells (RBCs).
Because of this:
•    Daratumumab binds to CD38 on RBCs, interfering with indirect antiglobulin testing (also known as the indirect Coombs test), which is essential for antibody screening, identification, and cross-matching.
•    This results in panreactivity, making it difficult to identify clinically significant alloantibodies.
•    To manage this, patients receiving daratumumab should ideally have a baseline blood type and extended phenotype/genotype recorded before treatment begins.
•    Blood banks may use special methods (e.g., dithiothreitol [DTT] treatment) to denature CD38 on RBCs and eliminate the interference.
Other options:
•    Rituximab (anti-CD20), trastuzumab (anti-HER2), and infliximab (anti-TNFα) do not interfere with RBC testing or cross-matching in this way.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs are known to potentially cause or worsen mental depression?

A. Zuranolone

B. Isotretinoin

C. Interferon-alpha

D. Corticosteroids

E. Montelukast
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:
B. Isotretinoin
•    A retinoid used for severe acne.
•    Linked to depressive symptoms, mood swings, and suicidal ideation in some individuals.
•    Though controversial, the association has prompted strong psychiatric warnings.

C. Interferon-alpha
•    Used in chronic hepatitis B/C and certain cancers.
•    Frequently causes major depression, fatigue, and cognitive impairment due to pro-inflammatory cytokine effects on the brain.

 D. Corticosteroids
•    High-dose or prolonged use can cause mood disturbances, including depression, anxiety, and even steroid-induced psychosis.
•    Mechanism involves altered HPA axis and neurotransmitter changes.

E. Montelukast
•    A leukotriene receptor antagonist used in asthma and allergic rhinitis.
•    Has a black box warning for neuropsychiatric effects, including depression, agitation, suicidal thoughts, especially in children and adolescents.

A. Zuranolone
•    This is a positive allosteric modulator of GABA-A receptors, recently approved for postpartum depression.
•    It is actually used to treat depression, not cause it.

questions.text: Which antimalarial drug is commonly used for malaria prophylaxis in travelers but is generally avoided in patients with a history of psychiatric illness due to the risk of causing psychosis or other neuropsychiatric effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mefloquine

Explanation:
Mefloquine is an effective antimalarial agent used for prophylaxis against Plasmodium falciparum, especially in areas with chloroquine resistance. However, it is associated with a significant risk of neuropsychiatric side effects, including:
•    Anxiety
•    Depression
•    Insomnia
•    Hallucinations
•    Frank psychosis
Because of these risks, mefloquine is contraindicated in individuals with a history of major psychiatric disorders, including depression, generalized anxiety, psychosis, or schizophrenia. This makes it unsuitable for travelers with such conditions.
Other options:
•    Doxycycline: Can cause GI upset and photosensitivity but not linked to psychosis.
•    Atovaquone-proguanil: Well-tolerated with mild GI or liver enzyme elevation in some cases; not associated with psychosis.
•    Chloroquine: Generally safe but limited by widespread resistance; not known for inducing psychosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding osteoporosis drugs is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Calcitonin is associated with an increased risk of hepatic cancer

Explanation:
•    A. Teriparatide →  True. Teriparatide is a recombinant PTH analog used for severe osteoporosis. Chronic use beyond 2 years is not recommended due to a theoretical risk of osteosarcoma, observed in rat studies.
•    B. Zoledronate →  True. Zoledronate is a bisphosphonate. Long-term suppression of bone remodeling may lead to atypical femoral fractures (often referred to as chalk-stick fractures), especially in the subtrochanteric region.
•    C. Calcitonin →  False. Calcitonin is a less commonly used antiresorptive agent. It has been associated with a slight increased risk of cancer, but not specifically hepatic (liver) cancer. Most concerns have been about prostate and basal cell cancers, and the evidence is not conclusive.
•    D. Denosumab →  True. Denosumab is a monoclonal antibody against RANKL. It can cause hypocalcemia, infections, and osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ) in some patients, particularly those with renal impairment.

questions.text: Match the following antiepileptic drugs with their primary mechanism of action:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation:
1.    Lamotrigine – Primarily acts by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels and also reduces the release of excitatory neurotransmitters like glutamate. This dual action makes it effective in both focal and generalized seizures.
2.    Gabapentin – Though it was designed as a GABA analog, its main mechanism is binding to the α2δ subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels, thereby decreasing excitatory neurotransmitter release. It's also used for neuropathic pain.
3.    Levetiracetam – Works by binding to SV2A, a synaptic vesicle protein, which modulates neurotransmitter release and reduces seizure activity. It has minimal drug interactions.
4.    Lacosamide – Uniquely enhances the slow inactivation of sodium channels (unlike phenytoin or carbamazepine, which affect fast inactivation), making it effective for focal seizures with a novel MOA.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Resmetirom

Explanation:
•    Resmetirom (brand name Rezdiffra) is the first FDA-approved drug (approved in March 2024) specifically for treating non-cirrhotic NASH with moderate to advanced fibrosis.
•    It is a selective thyroid hormone receptor-β (THR-β) agonist.
•    Its mechanism promotes hepatic fat metabolism and reduces liver fibrosis and inflammation, which are central features of NASH.
Other options:
•    A. Tirzepatide: A dual GLP-1/GIP receptor agonist approved for type 2 diabetes and obesity, shows promise in improving metabolic parameters and liver fat content but is not yet FDA-approved for NASH.
•    B. Liraglutide: A GLP-1 receptor agonist used in type 2 diabetes and obesity, studied in NASH but not FDA-approved for this indication.
•    D. Semaglutide: Another GLP-1 receptor agonist with investigational use in NASH, but not yet approved for it.

questions.text: Which of the following cephalosporins should be avoided in a patient on warfarin due to the increased risk of prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cefotetan

Explanation:
Warfarin is an anticoagulant that works by inhibiting the synthesis of vitamin K–dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X). Some cephalosporins, particularly those with an N-methylthiotetrazole (NMTT) side chain (like cefotetan and cefamandole), can also impair vitamin K–dependent clotting and interfere with gut flora that produce vitamin K.
When combined with warfarin, these cephalosporins can lead to additive effects on vitamin K antagonism, significantly increasing the risk of PT/INR prolongation and bleeding.
•    Cefotetan contains the NMTT side chain, which inhibits vitamin K epoxide reductase and can potentiate the anticoagulant effect of warfarin.
•    Other cephalosporins listed (e.g., ceftriaxone, cefalexin, cefuroxime) do not have this side chain and are less likely to cause significant interactions with warfarin in this manner.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman reports episodic vertigo lasting 20–30 minutes, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and ear fullness. Which condition is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Meniere’s disease

Ref:Read the text below

Sol:

•    Meniere’s disease is characterized by episodic vertigo (lasting 20 minutes to several hours), low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and ear fullness due to endolymphatic hydrops. 

•    BPPV causes brief (<1 minute) positional vertigo, while vestibular migraine lacks hearing loss.

Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is a rare neurological condition that can occur after measles infection. It's an inflammatory demyelinating disease of the central nervous system, meaning it causes inflammation and damage to the protective myelin sheath around nerve fibers in the brain and spinal cord. In measles, ADEM typically develops within days to weeks after the initial measles infection.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents to ER with pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath. Her ABG shows Pao2 of 55mm of Hg . She uses OCP. Her vital signs are: BP- 86/44 mmHg, P- 130/ min, RR- 30 /min, SpO2 85% on room air. Her ECHO reveals RV hypokinesia. What is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Anticoagulation plus thrombolysis

Patient is presenting with massive pulmonary embolism plus with ongoing hypotension, right
ventricular dysfunction, and hypoxemia - In this setting, the patient should receive circulatory support, anticoagulation with fibrinolysis, if there are no contraindications.

The recommended fibrinolytic regimen is recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA). 

Heparin should be continued with the fibrinolytic to prevent a rebound hypercoagulable state with
dissolution of the clot.

If the patient had contraindications to fibrinolysis and was unable to be stabilized with vasopressor
support, referral for surgical embolectomy should be considered.

questions.text: The syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is characterized by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone secretion (SIADH) is characterized by excessive release of ADH (vasopressin) despite normal or low plasma osmolality, leading to water retention and dilutional hyponatremia.

Key Features of SIADH:

•    Low serum osmolality (due to dilution by retained water)

•    Hyponatremia (dilutional)

•    Concentrated urine (inappropriately high urine osmolality and sodium)

•    Euvolemia clinically (no edema)

•    Normal renal, adrenal, and thyroid function

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true of primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

It is usually caused by an adenoma of a single parathyroid gland.

•    "Primary HPT can be divided pathologically into adenoma, hyperplasia, and carcinoma. Adenomas clearly are the most prevalent entity representing 80-85% of cases.
•    Hyperplasia is the second most common diagnosis constituting 15% of cases. Carcinoma represents <1% of total cases.
•    Double adenoma has been found in approximately 5% of the time, and complicates the clinical distinction between adenoma and hyperplasia.
•    Histologically, normal parathyroid tissue shows a cell to fat ratio of 1:1. Hypercellular parathyroid tissue is typified by the loss of the normal amount of fat. 
•    In primary hyperparathryroidism there is usually hypercalciuria. Secondary hyperparathyroidism may progress to tertiary but primary does not.

questions.text: Most commonly used rave party drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Amphetamine 

(Ref : Kaplan synopsis pg 679)

The use of a certain group of substances popularly called club drugs is often associated with dance clubs, bars, and allnight dance parties (raves). The group includes LSD, γ- hydroxybutyrate (GHB), ketamine, methamphetamine, MDMA (ecstasy), and Rohypnol or “roofies” (flunitrazepam). These substances are not all in the same drug class, and they do not produce the same physical or subjective effects. GHB, ketamine, and Rohypnol have been called date rape drugs because they produce disorienting and sedating effects, and often users cannot recall what occurred during all or part of an episode under the influence of the drug. Hence, it is alleged that these drugs might be surreptitiously placed in a beverage, or a person might be convinced to take the drug and then not recall clearly what occurred after ingestion. Emergency department mentions of GHB, ketamine, and Rohypnol are relatively few. Of the club drugs, methamphetamine is the substance that accounts for the largest share of treatment admissions.

questions.text: A 21-year-old ballet dancer, who is 5 feet 7 inches tall and has weighted 95 pounds (BMI = 14.5) for the past year, tells the doctor that she needs to lose another 15 pounds to pursue a career in dance. Her mood appears good. Findings on physical examination are normal except for excessive growth of downy body hair. She reports that she has not menstruated in more than 3 years. Which of the following disorders is this patient at the highest risk for in the future?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Osteoporosis 

This woman is already underweight yet wants to lose more weight, and she has developed lanugo (growth of downy body hair) and amenorrhea (absence of menses). These findings indicate that she has anorexia nervosa. Since dancers and gymnasts often must be small and slim, these activities are closely associated with the development of anorexia nervosa. Anorexia is also characterized by family conflicts, particularly with the mother; normal appetite; high interest in food and cooking; low sexual interest; good school performance; and excessive exercising. Patients who have anorexia nervosa for an extended period (5 years in this young woman) are at high risk for osteoporosis.

questions.text: A patient in a critical care unit for acute hypertensive crisis is on Sodium nitroprusside infusion. His pulse oximeter reading gradually starts to drop from 98% to 85%. Which of the following factors is most likely responsible for this change?

Explanation:

•    Certain medications and chemicals, such as local anesthetics containing benzocaine or prilocaine, can induce methemoglobinemia, resulting in inaccurate pulse oximeter readings.
•    Sodium nitroprusside can reduce haemoglobin to methaemoglobin which on accumulation can cause significant methemoglobinemia.

questions.text: A known alcoholic is brought to the emergency department by his wife. The person has not consumed alcohol for the past two days due to religious reasons. The person complained of nausea, vomiting and dizziness. On the second day, he developed seizures, that progressed to generalized tonic clonic seizures (GTCs). Which of the following would be the best medication to manage the seizures of the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Diazepam  

(Ref: Kaplan psychiatry 10th edition pg -399)

This is a clinical scenario often asked previously also in many exams. It is a case of alcohol dependence syndrome in withdrawal, complicated by withdrawal seizures. Remember following points: 

1. Seizures associated with alcohol withdrawal are stereotyped, generalized, and tonic-clonic in characterQ .

2. Patients often have more than one seizure 3 to 6 hours after the first seizure.  

3. Status epilepticus is relatively rareQ and occurs in less than 3 percent of patients. 

4. Although anticonvulsant medications are not required in the management of alcohol withdrawal seizuresQQ, the cause of the seizures is difficult to establish when a patient is first assessed in the emergency room; thus, many patients with withdrawal seizures receive anticonvulsant medications, which are then discontinued once the cause of the seizures is recognized. 

5. The primary medications to control alcohol withdrawal symptoms are the benzodiazepinesQ . Many studies have found that benzodiazepines help control seizure activity, delirium, anxiety, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, and tremor associated with alcohol withdrawal. 

6. Benzodiazepines can be given either orally or parenterally; neither diazepam nor chlordiazepoxide however, should be given intramuscularlyQ (IM) because of their erratic absorption by this route. 

7. Although benzodiazepines are the standard treatment for alcohol withdrawal, studies have shown that carbamazepine in daily doses of 800 mg is as effective as benzodiazepines(probable question) and has the added benefit of minimal abuse liability. 

8. The alpha 2-adrenergic receptor antagonists and clonidine(FOR PGI) have also been used to block the symptoms of sympathetic hyperactivity, but neither drug is an effective treatment for seizures or delirium.

questions.text: The CT scan shown below shows which form of congenital hydrocephalus?

Dandy-Walker malformation (DWM) refers to a complex developmental anomaly of the cerebellar vermis in which there is failure of the normal closure of the fourth ventricle with persistence of Blake's pouch that occurs in the 13th to 18th week of gestation, thus explaining some of the concurrent anomalies. 

Sonographic findings include all of the following:

•Persistent Blake's pouch cyst

•Enlarged posterior fossa with the upward displacement of the tentorium, transverse sinus, and torcular

•Complete or partial agenesis of the vermis

The Caldwell's view is a specific X-ray projection used primarily to evaluate the frontal and ethmoid sinuses as well as the orbits and nasal bones. It is taken with the patient’s head tilted forward so that the central X-ray beam passes through the nasion at a 15-degree angle caudally. This view provides a clear image of the frontal sinus, ethmoid air cells, and the orbital rims, making it ideal for assessing fractures or sinus pathology in these areas.

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with prostate cancer is being investigated. The bone scan is reported as a super scan with increased uptake in the bones and reduced activity in the kidney and soft tissue. What is the reason for this super scan appearance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis

A “super scan” appearance on a bone scintigraphy is characterized by diffusely increased radiotracer uptake in the skeleton with diminished or absent activity in the kidneys and soft tissues. This pattern suggests that virtually all of the administered radiotracer has been taken up by the bones, which typically occurs when there is extensive skeletal metastasis, especially osteoblastic metastases, as seen commonly in advanced prostate cancer. In this case, the intense and diffuse uptake in the bones is due to widespread bone metastases which cause high osteoblastic activity. As a result, little tracer remains for renal excretion, hence the reduced kidney and soft tissue visualization—this is what constitutes a super scan.

questions.text: What is the best imaging study for earliest diagnosis of cerebral infarct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Diffusion weighted MRI

Diffusion Weighted MRI (DWI) is the most sensitive and specific imaging modality for the earliest diagnosis of cerebral infarct, particularly in the hyperacute phase (within minutes to a few hours of onset). DWI detects cytotoxic edema caused by ischemia, which restricts the movement of water molecules in brain tissue. These changes can be visualized as early as 5–30 minutes after the onset of a stroke, much earlier than with other imaging techniques. This makes DWI invaluable in acute stroke management, guiding timely interventions such as thrombolytic therapy.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old male adolescent is undergoing a sports preparticipation evaluation in order to participate in competitive baseball. He has no notable medical history and is not currently on any medications. There is no family history of kidney disease. The boy's weight is at the 75th percentile, while his height is at the 90th percentile for his age group. His blood pressure reading is 110/70 mm Hg. The rest of his physical examination results are within normal limits. A urine sample was submitted to the laboratory for further analysis following a positive dipstick test for protein conducted in the office.

The results of urine testing are shown:
 
Of the following, the BEST next step in management of this adolescent is to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The adolescent boy in the vignette has asymptomatic proteinuria, as suggested by the findings of 2+ protein and a urine protein:creatinine ratio (UPCR) of 0.6 mg/mg on random urinalysis. The best next step in his evaluation is to obtain a first morning UPCR to confirm orthostatic proteinuria. If the first morning UPCR is normal (≤0.2 mg/mg), clearance for sports participation can be given. If the first morning UPCR is greater than 0.2 mg/mg, the boy should be referred to a pediatric nephrologist, and clearance for sports participation should be withheld pending that evaluation.

questions.text:
This is about a 12 yr old boy. His problems typically started in early adolescence with jerks in the morning, often causing to drop things; generalized tonic–clonic or clonic–tonic–clonic seizures upon awakening. Sleep deprivation and photic stimulation acted like precipitants. Following is his EEG. 

What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

JME

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome) is the most common generalized epilepsy in young adults, accounting for 5% of all epilepsies. It has been linked to mutations in many genes including CACNB4; CLNC2; EJM2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9; GABRA1; GABRD; and Myoclonin1/EFHC1. Typically, it starts in early adolescence with 1 or more of the following manifestations: myoclonic jerks in the morning, often causing the patient to drop things; generalized tonic– clonic or clonic–tonic–clonic seizures upon awakening; and juvenile absences. Sleep deprivation, alcohol (in older patients), and photic stimulation, or, rarely, certain cognitive activities can act as precipitants. The EEG usually shows generalized 4-5 Hz polyspike–and–slow wave discharges.

Comparison of maternal and infant antibody titers

questions.text:
A 13 mo old previously healthy child presents on New Year's Eve with a 2-day history of fever, lethargy, and irritability. Earlier this afternoon he began to have twitching movements of his left arm and on the left side of his face. His immunizations are up-to-date. Physical examination reveals fever with a temperature of 39°C and left-sided weakness, with no rashes. Examination of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) reveals 70 WBCs/mm 3 with 85% lymphocytes, 400 RBCs/mm3, protein of 140 mg/dL, glucose 80 mg/dL, and negative results on Gram stain.

MRI reveals right temporal abnormalities. The diagnostic study most likely to identify a treatable illness in a timely fashion is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

HSV PCR of CSF

HSV encephalitis is the leading cause of sporadic, nonepidemic encephalitis in children and adults in the USA. It is an acute necrotizing infection generally involving the frontal and/or temporal cortex and the limbic system and, beyond the neonatal period, is almost always caused by HSV-1. The infection may manifest as nonspecific findings, including fever, headache, nuchal rigidity, nausea, vomiting, generalized seizures, and alteration of consciousness. Injury to the frontal or temporal cortex or limbic system may produce findings more indicative of HSV encephalitis, including anosmia, memory loss, peculiar behavior, expressive aphasia and other changes in speech, hallucinations, and focal seizures. The untreated infection progresses to coma and death in 75% of cases. Examination of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) typically shows a moderate number of mononuclear cells and polymorphonuclear leukocytes, a mildly elevated protein concentration, a normal or slightly decreased glucose concentration, and often a moderate number of erythrocytes.

questions.text: A young lady presents to your office with complain of copious vaginal discharge, but there is no cervical discharge on per speculum examination. Which of the following should be given for the management?

questions.text:
A 2-year-old male child is being assessed for complaints of leg discomfort. He was adopted at the age of 15 months and did not begin walking until he was 18 months old. The child has not experienced any fractures. His diet is well-balanced, consisting of table foods and cow's milk. The adoptive parents have limited information regarding his biological family, except that the biological mother is notably short in stature. The physical examination reveals only significant bowing of both legs. A radiograph of the right knee indicates the presence of osteopenia, along with widened and frayed metaphyses.

Laboratory data are shown:
 
Of the following, the MOST likely cause of this boy’s findings is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The boy in the vignette has hypophosphatemic rickets due to X-linked hypophosphatemia (XLH), the most common inherited form of rickets. Children with XLH typically have symptoms and signs of rickets (eg, leg bowing in ambulating children, bone pain, pathologic fractures) and short stature. Dental abscesses are common. X-linked hypophosphatemia is inherited in an X-linked dominant fashion. The mother of the boy in the vignette is likely affected by XLH given her short stature. Low serum phosphate levels normally stimulate 1α-hydroxylase in the kidney to increase 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels, but this response does not occur in XLH. Parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels are usually normal in XLH because calcium levels are normal. The alkaline phosphatase level is elevated due to the high bone turnover state.

questions.text: A 4 yr old white girl has had a low-grade fever, intermittent crampy abdominal pain with emesis, and swollen knees for 3 days. There is a petechial rash on the lower extremity. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

HSP/ IgA vasculitis

The hallmark of HSP is its rash: palpable purpura starting as pink macules or wheals and developing into petechiae, raised purpura, or larger ecchymoses. The skin lesions are usually symmetric and occur in gravity-dependent areas (lower extremities) or on pressure points (buttocks). Musculoskeletal involvement, including arthritis and arthralgias, is common, occurring in up to 75% of children with HSP. The arthritis tends to be self-limited and oligoarticular, with a predilection for the lower extremities, and does not lead to deformities. The arthritis usually resolves within 2 wk but can recur. Gastrointestinal manifestations of HSP occur in up to 80% of children with HSP. They include abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, paralytic ileus, melena, intussusception, and mesenteric ischemia or perforation. Endoscopic evaluation usually is not needed but may identify purpura of the intestinal tract. Renal involvement occurs in up to 50% of children with HSP, manifesting as hematuria, proteinuria, hypertension, frank nephritis, nephrotic syndrome, and acute or chronic renal failure. Progression to end-stage renal disease is uncommon in children (1-2%).

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

TLD badge

TLD (Thermoluminescent Dosimeter) badge is the standard tool used for personal monitoring of radiation exposure. It contains a crystal that traps electrons when exposed to ionizing radiation. When heated later in a lab, the trapped electrons release light proportional to the radiation dose received. This allows accurate measurement of an individual's cumulative radiation exposure over a period, ensuring safety for healthcare workers and others who work around radiation sources.

questions.text: Identify the hormone by looking at the graph of the hormone in pregnancy:

PRL

questions.text: What would be the most likely diagnosis based on X-Ray of a new born child with a scaphoid abdomen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

A scaphoid abdomen in a newborn, especially when accompanied by respiratory distress and abnormal findings on chest X-ray (e.g., air-filled loops of bowel in the thoracic cavity), is a classic presentation of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). In CDH, abdominal contents herniate through a defect in the diaphragm—most commonly the left posterolateral (Bochdalek) foramen—into the thoracic cavity. This leads to compression of the developing lung, causing pulmonary hypoplasia, and a displacement of abdominal organs into the chest, which explains the scaphoid (sunken) abdomen due to absence of bowel loops in the abdominal cavity. The X-ray typically shows bowel gas patterns in the thoracic cavity with mediastinal shift.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not responsible for the following condition in an infertile patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Letrozole

This is a picture of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. Usg shows multiple large follicles. It is a life-threatening condition. Maximum risk is seen with HCG injection. Recombinant FSH or HMG therapy can also cause this condition. Clomiphene is a rare cause of OHSS. Letrozole is not associated with OHSS because it is responsible for uni-follicular ovulation.

questions.text: A 3 yr old girl presents to your office with acute onset of lethargy and pallor. The child's mother reports that the child had bloody diarrhea for 5 days that cleared 1 day before presenting to your office. She also notes acute onset of cola-colored urine. On examination, the patient is pale and lethargic. Blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. The most appropriate next step in diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

CBC, think of Shiga HUS

The hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is defined by the simultaneous occurrence of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury

choices.text: It is not allowed on day 8 of delivery
She has to follow up after puerperium for tubal ligation
Laparoscopic tubal ligation can be done after puerperium

questions.text: 32 years old P2L2, day 8 of normal delivery has come to the PNC opd and she wants to undergo tubal ligation. Which one of the following is correct about the given case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

All are correct

Puerperal tubal ligation is allowed only within seven days of delivery. It is done by mini-laparotomy procedure. If patient has come on day 8 then puerperal tubal ligation is denied. Tubal ligation can be done after puerperium is over. It will be called as interval tubal ligation. It can be done laparoscopically as well.

questions.text: A 32 years old P2L2 has continuous lower abdominal pain since last 2 weeks. She has dysmenorrhoea since last 2 years. On clinical examination, it was found that there is cervical motion tenderness and adnexal tenderness. Which of the following is not the possible differential diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Asherman syndrome

Adnexal tenderness and cervical motion tenderness are seen in ectopic, PID, endometriosis and tubo ovarian abscess. In Asherman syndrome, there are intrauterine adhesions hence there is no such finding in this syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following condition in active labour would require cesarean section compulsorily?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Brow presentation

Brow presentation is associated with mentor vertical diameter. It is equal to 14 cm. Hence vaginal delivery is not possible in brow presentation so we must do caesarean section in these cases.

questions.text: A 7 yr old child with a 3-yr history of cough, intermittent wheezing, and poor growth has 2 sweat chloride values of 36 and 41 mEq/L. Additional diagnostic testing to rule out cystic fibrosis should include:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Nasal potential difference measurement. 

The diagnosis of CF has been based on a positive quantitative sweat test (Cl– = 60 mEq/L) in conjunction with 1 or more of the following features: typical chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, documented exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, and a positive family history. With newborn screening, diagnosis is often made prior to obvious clinical manifestations such as failure to thrive and chronic cough. Diagnostic criteria have been recommended to include additional testing procedures. More than 60 mEq/L of chloride in sweat is diagnostic of CF when 1 or more other criteria are present. Threshold levels of 30-40 mEq/L for infants have been suggested. Borderline (or intermediate) values of 40 to 60 mEq/L have been reported in patients of all ages who have CF with atypical involvement and require further testing. Chloride concentrations in sweat are somewhat lower in individuals who retain exocrine pancreatic function but usually remain within the diagnostic range. The finding of increased potential differences across nasal epithelium, the loss of this difference with topical amiloride application, and the absence of a voltage response to a ß-adrenergic agonist have been used to confirm the diagnosis of CF in patients with equivocal or frankly normal sweat chloride values. An alternative test is DNA testing; the patient must have two mutations identified (over 1500 mutations are associated with CF, one of which is  DeltaF508 mutation).

questions.text: In which of the following cases, IUI is not the treatment used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tubal infertility

Intrauterine insemination is the treatment modality used in cases where there is difficulty related with coitus like erectile dysfunction, premature ejaculation, retrograde ejaculation and vaginismus. IUI is also used in unexplained infertility and minimal to mild endometriosis. Tubal infertility is treated by opening the obstruction or IVF therapy
